awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Exploring IoT Data Transparency in the Home through Creative Data Representations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project for engaging with artists and other citizens to generate new ideas for how network-connected devices can work in the home. These connected devices are called the Internet of Things (IoT). From baby monitors to door locks, the IoT connects computational and interactive artifacts to automate services like involving temperature, lighting, and security, to support everyday activities. This produces large amounts of data collected in the home. While home dwellers may benefit from IoT services, citizens need better transparency regarding: what data are collected, how and where they are stored, who they are shared with, and how they are analyzed and used, in conjunction with privacy concerns. This project holds promise for benefitting society by opening new avenues for empowering home dwellers to understand and engage with their data, contributing to making the IoT more open, responsible, ethical, and healthy. This has the potential to broadly impact data transparency and privacy, at a time when these concerns are paramount across human experiences of computing systems. By combining Arts and STEM disciplines, this work is also expected to generate interest in underrepresented communities, e.g., women and students in the Arts and Humanities.

This research will use research through design as a method to develop new techniques for privacy and transparency by engaging people with their own IoT data, through creative representations. To go beyond current data visualization practices, the researchers will collaborate with artists to create representations translating domestic data logs into (a) 3D data materializations printed in ceramic, and (b) data narratives in the form of short stories. Printed ceramics will build on the fact that touching and manipulating data can be a generative sensemaking activity. Short stories will capitalize on the ways people understand complex and abstract concepts through data narratives. As home dwellers’ data are transformed into these new representations, the research team will study how they provoke new understandings and reflections around data in the home. Expected contributions involve generating novel creative data representations and design implications that contribute to transparency and privacy in people’s relationships with the forms and functions of IoT data in the home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project team developed two novel creative data representations for home Internet of Things data. We created two projects: the Data Epics and the Inner Ear. In the Data Epics, seven households shared home IoT data with seven fiction writers who wrote personalized fiction stories grounded in the data for the households to read. In the Inner Ear project, six households collected vibration data via a ceramic artifact we built and we materialized that data into ceramic rings for them. Printed ceramics build on the fact that touching and manipulating data can be a generative sensemaking activity. Short stories capitalize on the ways people understand complex and abstract concepts through narratives.

In both projects, we both collected data about the design and making process (in a Research-through-Design methodological tradition) and we interviewed participants to understand their experience in encountering their own data in this new form. Our goal was to investigate how questions of privacy and transparency with data could be examined through these creative avenues. We found that creative data physicalization led to more interest, curiosity, questions, and engagement from the participants, in particular because they were looking at their own data. In a way, the projects exemplified common critiques about data (the lack of privacy, the potential misrepresentation of self, the ongoing assumptions made based on data), but the difference was that participants didn’t simply read the critiques, but experienced them. This demonstrates how defamiliarization works as a tool to move away from a sense of doom or detachment many participants felt with regards to managing questions of privacy and transparency before the studies. In addition, by creating alternative representations of data, we were able to unmake (challenge and deconstruct) existing shared sociotechnical imaginaries about data and make new ones. Participants and collaborators in the projects were able to see data as malleable, subjective, interpretive, small, imperfect, and contingent, as opposed to clean, perfect, big, stable, and raw (often assumed ideas of data).

During the design process, findings included articulating how designers have to work through questions of legibility, aesthetics, infrastructure, labor, intimacy, and creative agency when working with data physicalization for personal data. We developed workflows that other designers and researchers will be able to follow, as well as guiding principles. Furthermore, we examined the role of interpretation in working with data (through data physicalization) and presented it as central to further work with home data. This forces designers (or technologists, engineers) to accept the subjectivity of their work and acknowledge their positionality.

Finally, the team investigated and found that existing home IoT data has limited access for home dwellers. To further support personal engagements with people’s own data, we will need new regulation and interfaces that make access easier.

The outcomes of the project were shared in academic settings like conferences and publications, as well as in the public realm with two websites: www.dataepics.studio and www.inner-ear.studio . In addition, during the duration of this award, the PI worked with students in design, art, humanities, and engineering, at undergraduate and graduate levels. This interdisciplinary side of the work is important as it develops pathways for students in disciplines outside engineering to also participate in the framing and development of our lives with data and technology in the future.
